Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

The diagram above shows the equipotential lines in a region of space in the vicinity of three charges. Several of the lines are labeled with their electric potential values. The difference between successive equipotential lines is <math alttext="1 volt" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The region is divided into squares that are <math alttext="1 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> wide. The points A through D are locations in the plane of the page.

(a) Rank the points A through D according to the magnitude of the electric field at those points. If any of the electric fields have equal magnitudes, explicitly state this. Explain your ranking.
(b) State the direction of the electric force acting on a proton placed at point B. Justify your answer.
(c) Estimate the strength of the electric field at point D. Justify your answer.

A glass tube is set between points A and B. A small negatively charged sphere is placed in the tube at point A and given an initial rightward velocity so that the sphere reaches point B, constrained by the tube to move along the line connecting A and B. Ignore any effects from friction or gravity.

(d) Describe how the speed of the sphere changes as it travels from A to B. Justify your answer.
(e) Describe how the acceleration (magnitude and direction) of the sphere changes as it travels from A to B. Justify your answer.

The charges that created the electric potential are removed and replaced by two other charges. The diagram above shows equipotential lines in the region of space that includes the tube and points A and B. The negatively charged sphere is again placed at point A, but it is this time released from rest. The mass and charge of the sphere are known. A student analyzing the situation writes a correct equation for the electric potential <math alttext="V of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> within the tube, where <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance traveled to the right from point A.

(f) There is a single location between point A and point B where the speed of the sphere reaches a maximum. Describe how a student can use the equation for <math alttext="V of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the maximum speed attained by the sphere.
